intro: Ramona incana, commonly known as the rough ramona, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its woody stems, hairy leaves, and showy yellow flowers that bloom in the spring. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in rocky soils and along riverbanks. Due to its unique morphology and ecological role, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists.
